Fraud in England and Wales: year ending December 2017

Attempted fraud and fraud offences involving a loss. Including cyber crime, computer misuse, false accounting, and banking and credit industry fraud.

Release date: 26 April 2018
Next release: 19 July 2018 (provisional)

This page is part of the latest release | View all pages in this release or view previous releases

No change in the volume of fraud offences in the last year

England and Wales, year ending March 2012 to year ending December 2017

Source: Action Fraud, National Fraud Intelligence Bureau (NFIB)

On this page you can:

  • Get an overview of the main findings for fraud
  • Get the data
  • Learn how we measure these statistics
  • Read a glossary of terms
  • Find more pages in this release
  • Contact us

Main findings for fraud

No increase in the amount of fraud

3.2 million fraud offences were measured by the Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW). This has not increased from the results of last year’s survey.

Eiusmod excepteur veniam aute veniam ad eiusmod eiusmod anim labore laboris fugiat occaecat. Magna nisi esse sunt reprehenderit est laborum cillum velit deserunt.

The number of incidents referred to the National Fraud Intelligence Bureau (NFIB) was also unchanged. The recorded crime series incorporates fraud offences collated by the NFIB from Action Fraud, Cifas, UK Finance and incidents referred to the police for investigation.

Eiusmod excepteur veniam aute veniam ad eiusmod eiusmod anim labore laboris fugiat occaecat. Magna nisi esse sunt reprehenderit est laborum cillum velit deserunt.

This series recorded a similar volume of fraud offences recorded in England and Wales in the year ending December 2017 (639,457 offences) compared with the previous year (639,476 offences).

Drop in offences such as investment fraud or charity fraud

The only category of fraud to show a significant change was “other fraud” (down 64%, from 97,000 to 35,000 offences).

  • Statistically significant change at the 5% level is indicated by an asterisk.
  • Non-investment fraud has been renamed as 'Consumer and retail fraud' to reflect the corresponding name change to the Home Office Counting Rules from April 2017.

Eiusmod excepteur veniam aute veniam ad eiusmod eiusmod anim labore laboris fugiat occaecat. Magna nisi esse sunt reprehenderit est laborum cillum velit deserunt.

Small fall in banking and credit industry fraud, cheque, card and online bank account fraud

Although there was no overall change, differences were shown in the number of offences recorded in the last year.

Overall offences showed:

  • Cifas fell by 7% (down to 283,284 offences)
  • UK Finance fell by 6% (down to 82,575 offences)

The falls reported by both Cifas and UK Finance were due largely to a volume decrease in “banking and credit industry fraud", with UK Finance showing a fall of 6% (to 82,575 offences), and Cifas showing a fall of 5% (to 244,968 offences).

Elit aliquip velit cupidatat cupidatat eu fugiat esse adipisicing esse fugiat proident commodo qui non reprehenderit deserunt.

This latest decrease reported by Cifas follows a period of increases seen in this type of fraud, and is driven largely by a decrease in “cheque, plastic card and online bank accounts fraud” (down 5% to 169,504 offences).

Cifas also reported a 3% decrease in the latest year in the number of incidents of “application fraud” referred to NFIB. This includes opening up an account using fake or stolen documents in someone else’s name.

Eiusmod excepteur veniam aute veniam ad eiusmod eiusmod anim labore laboris fugiat occaecat. Magna nisi esse sunt reprehenderit est laborum cillum velit deserunt.

Again, this latest decrease in application fraud reported by Cifas follows previous large rises and is thought to reflect a return to normal levels after a spike in reporting in September 2016, as well as banks taking more preventative measures, in turn resulting in fewer fraudulent applications getting through the screening process.

Rate of fraud in Southern England slightly higher than in Wales or northern England

The latest police force area data show there was generally less variation in rates of fraud by police force area than for most other types of crime, although rates for force areas in southern England were generally a little higher than those among force areas in Wales or northern England.

More about the data used in this bulletin

Fraud data is provided by Action Fraud – the public-facing national fraud and cybercrime reporting centre, as well as two industry bodies, Cifas and UK Finance, who report instances of fraud where their member organisations have been a victim.

Further information on each of the Fraud data sources and the differences between them can be found in Section 5.4 of the User guide to crime statistics for England and Wales and also in the Overview of fraud and computer misuse statistics article.

Information about these statistics

How do we measure this?

There are two main sources of data for this release:

  1. Crime Survey of England and Wales
    The Crime Survey of England and Wales (CSEW) is a survey which asks people whether they have been victims of a crime over the past 12 months.
  2. Police recorded crime
    Police recorded crime is crime that has been reported to the police, and recorded as part of police casework.

Police recorded crime data are not designated as National Statistics.

More information on both these sources can be found in the User guide to crime statistics for England and Wales.

More information on the methodology can be found in the Crime in England and Wales Quality and Methodology Information report.

What do you need to know about these numbers?

Strengths and limitations of the data
The Crime Survey of England and Wales (CSEW) is a survey which asks people whether they have been victims of a crime over the past 12 months. The survey has been consistent since 1981 and therefore is the best source to use when looking at trends over time. It is also a better measurement of crimes which are less likely to be reported to the police, such as, sexual offences.

Police recorded crime is crime that has been reported to the police, and recorded as part of police casework, making these figures sensitive to changes in policing practices and victims’ willingness to report crime. Therefore, an increase in the number of crimes recorded by the police does not necessarily mean that crime itself has increased. While it is good for understanding how much work police forces are carrying out, it is not a useful way to monitor trends and we do not recommend using it for exploring crime trends.

Police recorded crime is a good measurement of:

  • Homicide
  • Firearm / gun crimes
  • Crimes involving a weapon

Police recorded crime data are not designated as National Statistics.

Time periods covered
The latest Crime Survey for England and Wales figures presented in this release are based on interviews conducted between January 2017 and December 2017, measuring peoples’ experiences of crime in the 12 months before the interview.

The latest recorded crime figures relate to crimes recorded by the police during the year ending December 2017 (between January 2017 and December 2017).

In this release:

  • “latest year” (or “latest survey year”) refers to the (survey) year ending December 2017
  • “previous year” (or “previous survey year”) refers to the (survey) year ending December 2016

The Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) provides the best indication of the volume of fraud offences directly experienced by people. CSEW estimates cover a wide range of fraud offences, including attempts and offences involving a loss, and include incidents not reported to the authorities.

The number of incidents estimated by the CSEW is substantially higher than the number of incidents referred to the National Fraud Intelligence Bureau (NFIB), as the survey captures a large volume of lower-harm cases that are less likely to have been reported to the authorities.

The CSEW suggests that less than one-fifth (17.3%) of incidents of fraud either come to the attention of the police or are reported by the victim to Action Fraud (Table E7, year ending March 2017).

Action Fraud recorded lower than normal monthly volumes of fraud offences between July 2015 and April 2016, following the company contracted to provide the call centre service going into administration6. Volumes have recovered but because the lower-volume months form part of the comparator year (year ending December 2016), the latest figure will have been influenced by this issue, albeit to a lesser extent than seen previously.

National Statistic

Certified by the UK Statistics Authority as compliant with its Code of Practice for Official Statistics.
Learn more

Glossary

Fraud
Fraud involves a person dishonestly and deliberately deceiving a victim for personal gain of property or money, or causing loss or risk of loss to another.

Fraud by false representation
Where a person makes a representation that they know to be untrue or misleading. This covers a broad range of fraudulent activity, including dating scams (where the intended victim is befriended by a fraudster online and tricked into sending them money for a variety of emotive reasons), lottery scams (where the potential victim is told they have won a non-existent lottery prize and needs to pay a fee to release the winnings) and inheritance fraud (offering the false promise of an inheritance to trick victims into paying money or sharing bank or credit card details).

Other fraud
Types of fraud where the number of offences are considered too small for measurement by the survey are covered by the “other fraud” category. This includes offences such as charity fraud, frauds by false representation and obtaining services dishonestly.

Banking and payment card frauds
The most prevalent type of fraud, usually involving falsely obtaining or using personal bank or payment card details in order to carry out fraudulent transactions.

Computer misuse crime
Covers any unauthorised access to computer material, as set out in the Computer Misuse Act 1990 (Annex 2 provides further information). This is not limited to desk or laptop computers and can include any device using operating software accessible online, for example, games consoles, smart phones and smart TVs. It includes offences such as the spread of viruses and other malicious software, hacking and distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks (the flooding of internet servers to take down network infrastructure or websites).

A comprehensive guide to crime types and definitions can be found in the ONS User Guide

Crime in England and Wales

Over the long-term, crime has fallen, but some crimes have risen slightly in the previous 12 months.

Little change in levels of violent crime in recent years.

Weapons crime in England and Wales

Police recorded 7,130 (22%) more crimes involving weapons, with knife crime in cities rising most.

Corrections

19 July 2018 10:36

A correction has been made to the figure for increase in hospital admissions, in the first bullet point of the Main points and in Section 7: Some weapons offences are rising, but this type of crime remains rare.

This was due to a small error when using the incorrect time series data point.

We apologise for any inconvenience.
